question: Question_06_(b)
statement:
Seeds are dispersed from a tree in all directions uniformly. The density
of seeds that lands on the ground at a distance \emph{r} away is
approximately described by the function

\[s(r) = 50 \sin\left(\frac{\pi r}{10}\right) \text{ seeds/m}^2, \quad 0 \leq r \leq 10 \text{ m}\]

What is the total number of seeds on the ground within a 10 m radius of
the tree?
sols:
The total number of seeds is the sum of all $m^2$ around the tree times
the passend concentration of seeds.

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{Math_Exam_Resources_Courses_MATH103_April_2009_Question_6_(b)_picture_1.jpg}
\caption{Math\_Exam\_Resources\_Courses\_MATH103\_April\_2009\_Question\_6\_(b)\_picture\_1.jpg}
\end{figure}

Because the area around the tree is a ring, the field of seeds looks
like a the function rotated around the tree (y-axis).

To calculate this integral, we use the shell method
$\displaystyle \int 2\pi xh(x)dx$

For integration we use integration by parts.

\begin{align*}
\int_0^{10} 2\pi \underbrace{r}_{=u}50\underbrace{\sin\left(\frac{\pi r}{10}\right)dr}_{dv} &= 
100\pi\left[\left.-r\cos\left(\frac{\pi r}{10}\right)\frac{10}{\pi}\right|_0^{10} + 
\frac{10}{\pi}\int_0^{10}\cos\left(\frac{\pi r}{10}\right)dr\right]\\
&= 100\left[-10\cdot 10\cos(\pi) + 0 + 10\left.\sin\left(\frac{\pi r}{10}\right)\frac{10}{\pi}\right|_0^{10}\right]\\
&= 10000.
\end{align*}

There are 10000 seeds around the tree.
hints:
We have the density $s$ of seeds per $m^2$ given and are searching for
the number of seeds. So, an integral must be involved in the
calculation.

The seeds lay radially symmetric around the tree. So, it is a circular
area with radius $10m$, where the seeds are distributed.

The volume of the seeds are a solid of revolution with the function
$s(r)$ rotated around the tree (=y-axis).

For the solid of revolution use the shell method $\int 2\pi x h(x)dx$.

For the integration use integration by parts.
